analytic.title: This article has been accepted for inclusion in a future issue of this journal. Content is final as presented, with the exception of pagination

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: JADE is a differential evolution (DE) algorithm and has been shown to be very competitive in comparison with other evolutionary optimization algorithms. However, it suffers from the premature convergence problem and is easily trapped into local optima. This article presents a novel JADE variant by incorporating chaotic local search (CLS) mechanisms into JADE to alleviate this problem. Taking advantages of the ergodicity and nonrepetitious nature of chaos, it can diversify the population and thus has a chance to explore a huge search space. Because of the inherent local exploitation ability, its embedded CLS can exploit a small region to refine solutions obtained by JADE. Hence, it can well balance the exploration and exploitation in a search process and further improve its performance. Four kinds of its CLS incorporation schemes are studied. Multiple chaotic maps are individually, randomly, parallelly, and memoryselectively incorporated into CLS. Experimental and statistical analyses are performed on a set of 53 benchmark functions and four real-world optimization problems. Results show that it has a superior performance in comparison with JADE and some other state-of-the-art optimization algorithms.

They emulate biological behaviors that can be transformed into a search mechanism, such as prey actions and productive behaviors. The resulting search process shows a very strong performance via the best individuals continuously optimized over generations.

Various meta-heuristics are inspired by nature-inspired mechanisms. For example, genetic algorithm (GA) [1], differential evolution (DE) [2], evolution strategy (ES) [3], and biogeography-based optimization algorithm (BBO) [4] use an evolutionary mechanism. Ant colony optimization (ACO) [5], particle swarm optimization (PSO) [6], and artificial bee colony algorithm (ABC) [7] adopt a swarm intelligence mechanism. Gravitational search algorithm (GSA) [8] and colliding bodies optimization (CBO) [9] are implemented by a physicsbased mechanism. Mine blast algorithm (MBA) [10] and teaching-learning-based optimization (TLBO) [11] contain a human-related mechanism.

DE is a very effective optimization algorithm that has attracted much attention [12]- [19]. New variants of DE have been proposed to improve its performance, such as EPSDE [20], SHADE [21], SaDE [22], jDE [23], and JADE [24]. JADE is a successful one that adopts a mutation strategy called DE/current-to-pbest with optional external archive. Its control parameters are updated via an adaptive method to ensure that individuals keep their diversity to improve the search ability in its whole search phase. Although it has a good search performance, it cannot avoid sticking into local optima, thereby obtaining the inferior solutions.

Chaotic local search (CLS) emerges as a viable choice by taking advantages of the randomicity and ergodicity of chaos. It has been combined with many meta-heuristic optimization algorithms and received impressive success in improving their performance, e.g., chaotic DE [25] and chaotic GSA [26]. Their results show that CLS can remarkably improve search ability and alleviate the problem of falling into local optima.

To fully exploit the properties of chaos, we propose a chaotic-local-search-based JADE (CJADE). It can be a single and multiple chaos-embedded CJADE. The former is called CJADE-S. The latter uses CLS under a selection mechanism with the combination of 12 different chaotic maps. This mechanism can be random, parallel and memory-based selection, thereby leading to three variants called CJADE-R, CJADE-P, and CJADE-M, respectively. To examine their performances, 25 CEC2005 test functions, 28 CEC2013 benchmark functions, and 4 real-world engineering problems are 2168-2216 c 2019 IEEE. Personal use is permitted, but republication/redistribution requires IEEE permission.
See http://www.ieee.org/publications_standards/publications/rights/index.html for more information.
used. In addition, the performance of CJADE-M is analyzed in detail.

Section II reviews the history of chaos in heuristic optimization algorithms. Section III gives a brief description of JADE. Section IV introduces the CLS. Sections V and VI show and analyze the experimental results on benchmark test functions and real-world problems. Section VII exhibits several discussions regarding the effect of CJADE-M. Section VIII draws some important conclusions.

div.head: II. CHAOS IN HEURISTIC OPTIMIZATION ALGORITHMS
div.p: Apparently showing an irregular motion, chaos is a characteristic frequently encountered in nonlinear dynamic systems. It is seemingly an unpredictable random behavior which can be exhibited by a deterministic nonlinear system in deterministic conditions. Because of its ergodicity and randomicity, a chaotic system changes randomly and eventually goes through every state in the search space when the time duration is long enough. Since optimization time is often limited, a chaotic system should be incorporated into global optimizers (such as PSO and GA) to enhance the latter's search ability while avoiding any premature convergence. Chaos has been implemented in many applications along with the development of nonlinear dynamic systems [27]. Its applications to optimization algorithms fall into two categories.

div.head: A. Chaotic Maps and Sequences
div.p: Chaotic maps are mostly used to replace random values and adjust parameters in a population initialization and iteration procedure. In evolutionary algorithms (EAs) [28], they have been adopted in selection, crossover, and mutation operations to compare with the sequences generated by random number generators (RNGs). It is demonstrated that chaotic maps are more suitable for EAs than RNGs. Besides EAs, they have also been implemented in other heuristic algorithms, such as an immune system algorithm [29] and GA [30]. In these bio-inspired optimization algorithms, they are mostly applied to population initialization and adjustment of crossover and mutation operators.

A number of chaotic PSOs have been devised. Alatas et al. [31] proposed a chaos embedded PSO to ensure the search ergodicity for exploring an entire search space by using chaotic sequences. Results show its great performance in comparison with other improved PSOs. Afterward, they propose another improved chaotic PSO to handle data mining problems [32]. Gandomi et al. [33] improved a PSO by using multiple chaotic maps to adjust its attraction parameter. These attempts produce competitive results. Random parameters in its velocity update equation [34], [35] and inertia weight [36] have also been replaced by chaotic maps.

With regard to the application of chaotic sequences on DE, Coelho and Mariani [37] proposed a new method that combines DE with chaotic sequences and sequential quadratic programming (SQP) technique (DEC-SQP) to solve economic dispatch problems. DE with chaotic sequences are utilized as the global optimizer and the SQP technique is used to finetune the DE run in a sequential manner. With regard to the DE with chaotic sequences, it applies three approaches based on a logistic map to generate the mutation factor. This combination method is proven to be effective for economic dispatch problems [38]. Dos Santos Coelho et al. [39] proposed another DE algorithm based on Gaussian probability distribution, gamma distribution and chaotic sequence (DEGC). The mutation factor is initialized according to a formulation that utilizes the Gaussian probability distribution. The logistic map is used to generate a chaotic sequence to update the mutation factor during the search procedure, while gamma distribution is involved in the generation of a crossover rate. It should be noticed that each dimension of each individual in the population has a specific mutation factor which can fully exert the ergodicity of chaos. The authors argue that DEGC is less susceptible to premature convergence and less likely to be stuck in local optima.

Chaotic properties have been used in other newly proposed swarm intelligence optimization algorithms, such as chaotic BBO [40], chaotic bat algorithm [29], [41], chaotic cuckoo search [42], chaotic fruit fly optimization algorithm [43], chaotic krill herd algorithm [44], firefly algorithm with chaos [45], chaotic harmony search algorithm [46], and chaotic imperialist competitive algorithm [47]. These algorithms gain remarkable performance improvement by using chaotic sequences to replace random variables and parameters.

div.head: B. Chaotic Local Search
div.p: Chaotic maps for adjusting parameter values are one kind of efficient methods to enhance population diversity and solution quality; while implementing chaotic search is a way to improve search precision and accelerate convergence. Such implementations lead to a chaotic optimization algorithm (COA) and CLS. The former uses chaotic characteristics and has a faster search speed than stochastic algorithms [48]. In [49] a mutative scale COA is proposed and in [50] the proposed adaptive mutative scale COA improves search precision and efficiency. In [51] an attempt to use multiple chaotic maps for adjusting optimization variables is made such that COA is insensitive to an initial condition. Yuan et al. [52] added a parallel optimal objective function into COA to find a better solution in each iteration. In [53], eight different chaotic maps with different probability distributions are tested to find which chaotic map is the most suitable for COA.

CLS is also useful to help a global optimizer improve its performance and convergence. Exploration and exploitation are two main phases in an optimization process. Their balance controls convergence speed and decides solution quality. In chaotic PSO [54], an adaptive inertia weight factor is used to balance exploration and exploitation. CLS is implemented for the best particle in order to maintain population diversity and improve solution quality, which ensures a proper balance between exploration and exploitation. The results demonstrate that chaotic PSO is much better than traditional PSO, suggesting the effectiveness of CLS in improving PSO. In [55], a piecewise linear chaotic map is considered better than a logistic map when applied to CLS combined with PSO. In chaotic ABC [46], chaotic variable and CLS are used in two algorithms CABC1 and CABC2, respectively. Both are combined into CABC3, CABC2, and CABC3 using CLS achieve much better performance than CABC1 using only chaotic variable in initializing an artificial colony. The similar conclusion is drawn in [26] where random values are replaced by a chaotic sequence and CLS is added into GSA. Other optimization algorithms combined with CLS can be found in [56]- [59].

Especially, CLS has been incorporated into DE and achieves a great success. Jia et al. [25] proposed a CLS with a shrinking strategy to improve the optimization performance of DE (DECLS). A logistic map is adopted to generate a chaotic sequence. CLS length is defined by this chaotic sequence to help explore the whole search space. The search radius is shrinking according to the current function evaluations. Thus, DECLS can explore promising space at the early stages, and can keep intensity for the solutions with higher precision at later stages.

Guo et al. [60] proposed an elite CLS (ECLS) which adopts a logistic map to enhance the performance of DE. In ECLS, the elite individual is randomly chosen from the top 100p% individuals, where p is a randomly generated value. The candidate individual generated by ECLS takes feedback from the elite individual and the individual on which ECLS is applied. The chaotic sequence generated by a logistic map is used as a parameter to vary the search radius. Besides ECLS, a simple and effective parameter adaptation mechanism is employed to enhance the robustness. The experimental results showed that ECLS-based DE is very competitive.

Ding and Zheng [61] proposed a CLS-based cellular DE (ccDE). A parallel evolution is first used to balance the exploration and exploitation tradeoff for DE. Then, CLS is applied to avoid immature convergence and search stagnation. At last, ccDE employs an orthogonal crossover operator instead of using a binomial crossover operator, which is considered to be effective in improving convergence speed and maintaining population diversity. Specifically, CLS used in it is the same as that in [25], including a logistic map and shrinking strategy. It is shown to achieve better performance in terms of convergence rate and solution accuracy than other algorithms.

div.head: C. Some Remarks
div.p: A number of COAs have verified that chaotic maps and CLS can bring performance improvements to their original ones, showing that chaos has distinctive search characteristics for EAs. However, there are many chaotic maps and CLS that can be adopted. The issues about how many chaotic maps and what kind of CLS are more beneficial for enhancing EAs are not comprehensively investigated to our best knowledge. Their number and methods can significantly consolidate the performance of EAs. Thus, we aim to study these two issues on JADE to provide more systematic analyses and convincing conclusions.
The remarkably valuable findings of this article are:

1) Multiple chaotic maps can better enhance the performance of CLS than a single one. 2) A chaotic sequence of memory-based selection is superior to a single, random, or parallel one. This selection mechanism can effectively invoke multiple chaotic sequences to implement different search processes. 3) Memory-based selection with multiple chaos performs better than it with a single one. Twelve chaotic maps are concluded as the best choice. Twelve chaotic maps together with the memory-based selection method well improve the performance of JADE.

div.head: III. BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF JADE
div.p: JADE uses a mutation method called DE/current-to-pbest. Compared to the classic DE/current-to-best, the best 100p% individuals in JADE are selected to offer individual evolution, where p ∈ (0, 1]. In its mutation procedure, a new individual depends on randomly selected one from the best 100p% individuals. The mutation procedure is described as
div.formula: V i (k) = X i (k) + F i X p best (k) -X i (k) + F i (X r1 (k) -X r2 (k)) (1)
div.p: where V i (k) and X i (k) indicate the ith newly generated and previous individuals in generation k, respectively. X p best (k) is a randomly selected individual from the best 100p% individuals. X r1 (k) is a randomly selected individual from the population. JADE uses an external archive to store the parent vectors that are replaced by the trial vectors. X r2 (k) is randomly selected from the external archive. The size of an external archive equals to the size of population. When the size of its archive exceeds the threshold, a vector in it is randomly deleted to make space for a new one. F i ∈ [0, 1] is a mutation factor and each individual has its own F i
where C i represents a Cauchy distribution. μ F is a location parameter and is initialized to be 0.5. The update equation is formulated as follows:
div.formula: μ F = (1 -c)μ F + c L(S F ) (3
div.p: where c is a random value between 0 and 1. S F is the set of all F i that successfully generate better individuals. L is the Lehmer mean, described as
div.formula: L(S F ) = F∈S F F 2 F∈S F F . (4
div.p: Next, we have the crossover parameter CR i of individual X i
It is generated according to a normal distribution N with mean value μ CR and standard deviation 0.1. CR i is initialized to be 0.5. μ CR is updated as follows:
div.formula: μ CR = (1 -c)μ CR + c 1 |S CR | x∈S CR x (6)
div.p: where S CR is the set of all CR i that successfully generate better individuals. It should be denoted that if CR i exceeds the interval of [0, 1], it is adjusted to the closest bound. F i is also subject to this rule. Its mutation strategy, external archive, and adaptability of mutation factor F and crossover probability CR help it balance algorithmic exploration and exploitation, and provide high-quality solutions.

div.head: A. Motivation
div.p: To improve the solution quality and convergence speed of optimization algorithms, local search is a viable choice. Most optimization algorithms have desired exploration ability so as to ensure an acceptable convergence speed in their searching period, but in their exploitation period, they tend to stick into local optima. Local search methods are carried on the current global best individual only once at each generation because of two reasons: 1) there is a high possibility that a better solution could be found in the area near the current global best one and 2) comparing with implementing local search on all individuals, it can save much computational time. As mentioned before, chaos has the properties of ergodicity and randomicity, thus using sequences generated by chaotic maps to replace random sequences has foreseeable improvement in the search ability of optimization algorithms. Chaotic maps are given in the supplementary material.

In [26], a CLS using one chaotic map is proposed and experimental results demonstrate that the optimization algorithm combined with CLS can outperform the conventional one in convergence speed and solution quality. Based on this article, we introduce four CLS methods which implement 12 chaotic maps individually, randomly, parallelly, and memory-selectively, thereby resulting in CJADE-S, CJADE-R, CJADE-P, and CJADE-M.

div.head: B. CJADE-S
div.p: CJADE-S uses J (J = 12 in this article) chaotic maps to test the effect of CLS, respectively. CLS visits the current global best individual

where k denotes the kth iteration and D represents the dimension of the optimization problem. It should be noted that all dimensions of the vector use the same value of a chaotic map. In each iteration, CLS searches all dimensions of X g (k) in order to generate a new individual X g (k) as follows: (k) is better than the current global best fitness value X g (k), X g (k) replaces it to go to the next iteration, while the others stay the same to get into the next iteration. We call it a successful CLS. The individual updating procedure can be carried out as follows:
div.formula: X g (k + 1) = X g (k), if f X g (k) < f X g (k) X g (k), otherwise(8)
X i (k + 1) = X i (k) for i = 1, 2, . . . , N and i = g (9)
div.p: where N is the number of individuals. Moreover, the search radius is narrowed at each generation as follows: r = ρr (10) where ρ = 0.988 is a shrinking parameter.

div.head: C. CJADE-R
div.p: CJADE-S uses only one chaotic map in a run. As a result, a dynamic system keeps the same property and lacks variability. However, different chaotic maps have distinctive dynamic properties. Under this condition, the combination of multiple chaos is an effective method to improve the algorithm's search ability and solution quality.
In CJADE-R, each CLS randomly makes use of one chaotic map as follows:
div.formula: X g (k) = X g (k) + r(U b -L b ) z j (k) -0.5(11)
div.p: where z j (k) indicates the chaotic sequence generated by the jth chaotic map randomly selected from J chaotic maps. Equations ( 8) and ( 9) are used to update individuals. The difference between CJADE-S and CJADE-R is that CJADE-R randomly uses one chaotic map in each iteration. A chaotic map is selected by a random integer uniformly distributed in the interval [1, J]. Thus, each chaotic map is used with equal probability and abundant dynamic properties can occur in a whole search procedure so as to decrease the probability of trapping into local optima.

div.head: D. CJADE-P
div.p: CJADE-P means that a CLS parallelly uses all the sequences generated by J chaotic maps in each iteration, defined as follows:
div.formula: X j g (k) = X g (k) + r(U b -L b ) z j (k) -0.5 (12) X g (k) = argmin f X 1 g (k) , . . . , f X j g (k) , . . . , f X J g (k) . (13
div.p: Different from the meaning of j in CJADE-R, in CJADE-P it is selected from one to 12 in turn. After generating 12 temporary solutions, CJADE-P chooses the best one as the global best solution and then use (8) to update it. This method can significantly improve the algorithm's convergence speed and solution quality.

div.head: E. CJADE-M
div.p: In CJADE-M, one chaotic map is selected from J chaotic maps according to the learned probability from a success rate and a failure rate which are calculated from success and failure memories. We preset learning iteration count (L) at 50. In these learning iterations, chaotic maps are randomly selected like CJADE-R while the results of CLS are stored in the success and failure memories.
Let α k,j represent the number of successes and β k,j represent the number of failures at iteration k using the jth chaotic map. Initially, α 0,j = 0 and β 0,j = 0. They are updated according to
div.formula: α k,j = ⎧ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎩ α k-1,j + 1, if f X j g (k) < f X g (k) & k ≤ L α k-1,j , if f X j g (k) ≥ f X g (k) & k ≤ L α k-1,j + 1 -α k-L,j -α k-L-1,j , if f X j g (k) < f X g (k) & k > L α k-1,j -α k-L,j -α k-L-1,j , otherwise(14)

β k,j = ⎧ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎩ β k-1,j , if f X j g (k) < f X g (k) & k ≤ L β k-1,j + 1, if f X j g (k) ≥ f X g (k) & k ≤ L β k-1,j -β k-L,j -β k-L-1,j , if f X j g (k) < f X g (k) & k > L β k-1,j + 1 -β k-L,j -β k-L-1,j , otherwise. (15
div.p: If X j g (k) outperforms and replaces X g (k), we call it a success and add 1 to α k-1,j . Otherwise, it is a failure and add 1 to β k-1,j . If the iteration count is over L, the values of α k-L,j and β k-L,j are subtracted from α k,j and β k,j to make space for the newest ones (i.e., α k+1,j and β k+1,j ) which ensures only the number of successes or failures of the last 50 iterations is recorded.

The selection of chaotic maps is described as follows. In learning iterations, each chaotic map is chosen with an equal probability 1/J and memories record the results of CLS. After learning iterations, each chaotic map has its new chosen probability as follows:
div.formula: p k,j = S k,j J j=1 S k,j(16)
S k,j = α k,j α k,j + β k,j + ε (17
div.p: where p k,j denotes the chosen probability of the jth chaotic map in current iteration k. Equation ( 17) calculates the success rate and ε = 0.01 is used for avoiding a null value. It is obvious that the chaotic map with a higher success rate has a higher chance to generate new individuals via a roulette wheel selection method. X g (k) is used to generate a new individual X g (k) as shown in (11) and then their fitness values are compared in the jth chaotic map. Individuals are updated via (8) and (9). Fig. 1 depicts four selection schemes in chaotic maps to better interpret CJADE-S, CJADE-R, CJADE-P, and CJADE-M. Their procedure is given in the supplementary material.

div.head: F. Advantages of CJADE
div.p: Some similar works which include the applications of chaotic sequences and CLS have been reported. However, the previous work lacks a comprehensive discussion and cannot provide a perspective about the performance of chaos on DE. CJADE is a modified JADE variation which systematically investigates the performance of numerous chaotic maps and multiple CLS methods. The advantages of CJADE can be exhibited through the following comparisons.

Compared with the DEC-SQP [37] and DEGC [39], CJADE has two advantages that one is in the number of used chaotic maps, the other is the full utilization of ergodic property. The limitation in quantity leads to a lack in quality. Using only one chaotic map could not exhibit the superiority of chaos. In addition, different chaotic maps would have different performance when facing different problems. Thus, it is necessary to investigate the properties of numerous chaotic maps. Furthermore, adopting chaotic sequences to generate parameters in DE is not a proper way to fully exert the ergodicity of chaos. As a conclusion reported in [26] that CLS can improve the performance of meta-heuristics much better than other methods using chaos, CLS is a more flexible and effective way to enhance the performance of JADE.

Compared with the mentioned DECLS [25], DEECL [60], and ccDE [61], CJADE provides a comprehensive investigation about the performance of different chaotic maps and CLS methods. Logistic map is a commonly used chaotic map and has manifested considerable ergodic property in CLS. However, only one chaotic map has its limitation that it lacks of robustness when handling various problems. Thus, it is urgent to study the properties and performance of different chaos in CLS. Besides this, the implementing mechanisms of CLS also needs to be investigated because the current method is too simple to fully exert the ergodicity and randomicity of chaos. Although DECLS is proposed in 2011, its incorporation method of CLS is still adopted in ccDE which is proposed in 2015. This motivates us to introduce CJADE-S, CJADE-R, CJADE-P, and CJADE-M and conduct extensive experiments to expand the combination methods between CLS and DE.
In addition, although CJADE-M uses similar success and failure memory mechanisms as SaDE [22], they have three essential differences as follows.

1) SaDE stores the results of four-generation strategies and maintains a strategy candidate pool while CJADE-M records the performance of 12 chaotic maps. 2) SaDE uses a stochastic universal selection method to select one strategy whereas CJADE-M adopts a roulette wheel selection method to determine the most promising chaotic map. 3) In SaDE, each individual is updated by one from fourgeneration strategies according to the candidate pool. However, in CJADE-M, only the global best individual is optimized by one chaotic map with a higher success rate. To the best of our knowledge, we are the first to comprehensively investigate the properties of numerous chaotic maps and evaluate their performance in CLS. Furthermore, the random, parallel, and memory-selective combinations with chaos on DE are also newly proposed in this article. This work is expected to be a guidance for the utilization of chaos in other intelligent optimization methods.
V. EXPERIMENTS

div.head: A. Comparison Between JADE and CJADEs
div.p: In the experiment, we totally use 53 benchmark functions (F1-F53) to compare the performance between JADE and CJADEs. Twenty-five CEC2005 functions (F1-F25) which are rotated or shifted are chosen, which can be divided into unimodal and multimodal functions. Unimodal functions test the convergence speed of optimization algorithms and multimodal functions measure whether optimization algorithms can avoid falling into local optima. Twenty-eight newly proposed CEC2013 hybrid composition functions (F26-F53) are adopted to test their search ability. Numerous functions can intuitively show the improvements of CJADEs over JADE in terms of search ability.

The parameter setting is described as follows. The population size is 100 and the maximum number of function evaluations (M F ) is set to 10 000D where D = 30 is the dimension of a test function. Each function is tested for 30 independent runs in each algorithm and their mean and standard deviation are listed in the supplementary material. Moreover, CJADE-S is divided into 12 different algorithms called CJADE-1 to CJADE-12 according to 12 chaotic maps.

In the supplementary material, the best values of functions are highlighted in boldface. From them, we can see that most of CJADEs can obtain the best value and outperform JADE on 53 functions. To more precisely assess the performance of each algorithm, the Friedman test is adopted as a statistical analysis method to rank each one according to their search results. It is used to test the performance among different groups. The group with better performance gets a lower rank in each benchmark function. Table I summarizes the average rank that each algorithm obtains on total 53 functions and independently lists the results of CEC2013 functions because of their complexity and difficulty. Based on this table, it can be found that CJADE-M gets the top rank on all functions and CEC2013 test functions, indicating that CJADE-M has the best performance. Besides, we can find that CJADE-8 which uses Chebyshev map obtains the best rank in CJADE-S. It indicates that while a logistic map is commonly used, its performance in CLS is not the best. According to this article, a Chebyshev map is more promising to be frequently applied than a logistic map due to its performance.

Tables II andIII show unadjusted p-values and adjusted p-values of JADE and other CJADEs in comparison with CJADE-M on F1-F53 and F26-F53. The adjusted p-value is a relatively conservative value used to eliminate the family wise error rate [62]. These p-values smaller than 0.05 indicate the significant difference between CJADE-M and other compared algorithms. According to Tables II andIII, it can be concluded that CJADE-M significantly outperforms CJADE-S, CJADE-R, CJADE-P, and conventional JADE on both 53 and CEC2013 test functions, suggesting that: 1) CLS is an effective method to enhance the performance of JADE and 2) CJADE-M has the best performance.

To intuitively show the convergence of each algorithm, Fig. 2 is plotted to exhibit the average best-so-far solution and ratio of the best-so-far solution on F5. In Fig. 2(a), the vertical axis is the average best-so-far solution and the horizontal axis is the number of function evaluations. For clarity, the vertical axis in Fig. 2(b) is changed to the ratio of the best-so-far solutions where the average best-so-far solution of a compared algorithm is divided by that of JADE. Fig. 2 shows that CJADE-M has faster convergence speed than other algorithms and performs the best in terms of the lowest average best-so-far solution and ratio. Their corresponding box-andwhisker diagrams are plotted in Fig. 3. From it, CJADE-M shows a lower solution distribution, meaning that it has a better search ability than the others. All these statistical results demonstrate that CJADE-M is the most promising and competitive method to optimize benchmark functions and significantly outperforms the conventional JADE.

div.head: B. Comparison Between CJADE-M and Other DEs
div.p: In Section V-A, we have proved that CJADE-M is the most effective algorithm among CJADEs. To further show its superiority, we compare it with some state-of-the-art DEs, i.e., EPSDE [20], SHADE [21], SaDE [22], and jDE [23]. It should be noticed that SHADE is an effective optimization algorithm based on JADE and especially suitable for our comparison purpose.

In the supplementary material lists the experimental results on 53 functions. To analyze the difference between CJADE-M and state-of-the-art DEs, Friedman test and Wilcoxon signedrank test are adopted. Their corresponding statistical results are shown in Tables IV and V. In Table IV, it can be seen that CJADE-M has the best rank on all the functions, suggesting that it possesses the best performance. In Table V, the larger R + value CJADE-M obtains, the better performance it has. The p-value shows the significant difference between CJADE-M and others in both levels α = 0.05 and α = 0.1. According to Table V, it can be verified that CJADE-M significantly outperforms the other four state-of-the-art DEs and exhibits its superiority over them.

div.head: (b)
div.p: Fig. 4 displays an aggregate performance of five algorithms on all test functions. The vertical axis denotes the number of functions where the algorithm performs the kth best according to the Wilcoxon signed rank test. The horizontal axis indicates the top kth. It can be observed from Fig. 4 that CJADE-M is the top-1 performer among most functions (35 much higher than 24 of the second-best one, i.e., SHADE IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON SYSTEMS, MAN, AND CYBERNETICS: SYSTEMS The convergence performances of five algorithms on F5 are exhibited in Fig. 5. It is obvious that CJADE-M converges faster than other algorithms and has the best solution quality. Fig. 6 shows the solution distribution of five algorithms on F5. In Fig. 6, CJADE-M has the best median, smallest maximum, and minimum value. Especially, compared with SHADE which is another variant of JADE, CJADE-M outperforms it, demonstrating the effectiveness of using CLS in JADE.

div.head: C. Comparison Between CJADE-M and DECLS
div.p: In this section, our proposed CJADE-M is compared with an effective memetic DE based on CLS (DECLS). According to [25], 13 traditional benchmark functions and three CEC2005 functions are tested at = 25 and D = 100. M F is set to 8000D and each function is tested for 30 runs. In [25], DECLS is compared with some state-of-theart optimization such as DEahcSPX [63] which uses an local search method, IPOP-CMA-ES [64] (a) which obtains the best performance in CEC2005 special session on real parameter optimization and DEGL/saw [65] which utilizes the neighborhood of population. The experimental results show that DECLS has a high search ability and outperforms the others. Thus, it is an outstanding candidate used to compare with our CLS strategy. In the supplementary material shows the results of seven algorithms, including CJADE-M, DEGL/saw, jDE, DEahcSPX, SaDE, IPOP-CMA-ES, and DECLS at D = 25 and D = 100. It is clear that CJADE-M significantly outperforms its peers at the level of significance α = 0.05 at both D = 25 and D = 100. It should be noted that in [25], when DECLS is compared with IPOP-CMA-ES at D = 100, the p-value is too high to show any significant difference. While in our experiment, the p-value between CJADE-M and IPOP-CMA-ES is 0.02558, which is significant, suggesting that CJADE-M well outperforms DECLS. These results indicate that our proposed memorybased CLS strategy is more efficient than the CLS strategy used in DECLS.

div.head: VI. CJADE FOR REAL-WORLD OPTIMIZATION PROBLEMS
div.p: In this section, four real-world optimization problems from CEC2011 [66] are chosen to assess the performance of CJADE in engineering applications, and their specific descriptions are listed in the supplementary material. Eight peers are whale optimization algorithm (WOA) [67], CGSA-P [68], DE [2], brain storm optimization (BSO) [69], EPSDE [20], SHADE [21], SaDE [22], and jDE [23].

div.head: A. Frequency-Modulated Sound Waves Problem
div.p: Frequency-modulated sound waves problem (FMSWP) is important in modern music systems. Das and Suganthan [66] described this system to generate a sound to emulate a target sound. Each algorithm independently runs 30 times and results are listed in Table VI. CJADE-M has the best performance among all tested 12 algorithms according to the smallest mean, standard deviation, best value, and worst value in Table VI, implying CJADE-M is the best algorithm to solve FMSWP.

div.head: B. Lennard-Jones Potential Problem
div.p: Lennard-Jones potential problem (LJPP) is a potential energy minimization problem. The parameter setting is the same as that on FMSWP. The experimental results are recorded in Table VII. From it, four algorithms derive similar results, while CJADE-M gives the best performance.

div.head: C. Nonlinear Stirred Tank Reactor Problem
div.p: Nonlinear stirred tank reactor problem (NLSTRP) is a multimodal optimization problem. Table VIII shows the results. From it, CJADEs generally offer better (or very competitive) results than other algorithms, manifesting their advantages. Moreover, CJADE-M has the best mean, suggesting its superiority over all the tested peers.

div.head: D. Transmission Network Expansion Planning Problem
div.p: Results for transmission network expansion planning problem (TNEPP) are listed in Table IX. According to it, CJADE-M performs the best among all algorithms.

In these four real-world optimization problems, CJADE-M obtains the best performance in comparison with other algorithms. Hence, a conclusion can be drawn that CJADE-M has an effective optimization ability and can be applied to various engineering problems.

div.head: VII. DISCUSSIONS
div.p: The above experiments have verified that CJADE-M has the best performance on 53 benchmark functions and four real-world optimization problems. In this section, some discussions are given to further analyze several details about CJADE-M and find more valid proofs to show its effectiveness. The experiments in this section are implemented at population size N = 100, dimension D = 30, and maximum number of function evaluations M F = 10 000D.

div.head: A. Analysis of Random Sequences
div.p: We perform an experiment to compare the difference between chaotic and random sequences. The latter is generated from a uniform distribution in [0, 1] and a standard normal distribution, respectively. The local search using a uniform distribution is called JADE-U and the one using a normal one is called JADE-N.

The experimental results are listed in the supplementary material and Wilcoxon signed-rank test results are shown in Table X. From it, CJADE-M significantly outperforms JADE-U and JADE-N, meaning that chaotic sequences are more effective than random sequences. As mentioned before, CLS goes through every state of a search space if the time duration is long enough. Thus, the ergodicity and randomicity of chaos can help JADE improve its search ability. This experiment indicates that the combination of JADE and CLS is successful.

div.head: B. Number of Chaotic Maps
div.p: The number of chaotic maps can influence the performance of CJADE-M. To find their best number, five groups using three, six, nine, twelve, and fifteen different chaotic maps are added into CJADE-M, respectively. 3, 6, and 9 represents the first 3, 6, and 9 chaotic maps introduced before while 15 means 12 prior ones plus 3 new chaotic maps named Iterative map, Intermittency map, and Zaslavsky map. Three new chaotic maps are described in the supplementary material.

Table XI shows results obtained by the Friedman test in different number of chaotic maps. The experimental results are listed in the supplementary material. In Table XI, CJADE-M using 12 chaotic maps obtains the best rank which is the smallest among five groups and significantly outperforms it with other numbers of chaos. All these p-values are smaller than 0.001, indicating that too many or too few chaotic maps weaken the effect of CLS and 12 is suitable for CLS.

div.head: C. CJADE-M Using Chebyshev Map
div.p: According to the conclusion in Section VII-B, 12 can be considered as the most suitable number for implementing chaotic maps into CJADE-M, and in Table I, CJADE-8 using a Chebyshev map performs the best in CJADE-S on all test functions. Thus, CJADE-M using 12 different Chebyshev maps generated by 12 different parameters (CJADE-Chebyshev) is tested to compare with CJADE-M. These 12 parameters are 4.85, 4.95, 5.0, 5.2, 5.3, 5.4, 5.5, 5.65, 5.75, 5.85, 5.9, and 6.0.

The experimental results are listed in the supplementary material and Table XII exhibits the Wilcoxon signed-rank test result between CJADE-M and CJADE-Chebyshev. Although the Chebyshev map is considered as the most effective single chaotic map and 12 is the most suitable number for CLS, CJADE-Chebyshev is not successful. In Table XII, CJADE-M obtains R + = 1387.5 and p-value = 0, denoting it significantly outperforms CJADE-Chebyshev on most of problems. This result demonstrates that CLS using different chaotic maps can exhibit different dynamic properties to help CLS improve its search ability and obtain better solutions.

div.head: D. CGSA-P Versus CJADE-M
div.p: In [68], we propose a multiple chaos embedded GSA (CGSA-P) and experimental results show that it has the best performance. In this part, CGSA-P is compared with CJADE-M on 53 functions.

The experimental results are listed in the supplementary material and the p-value of CJADE-M compared with CGSA-P is exhibited in Table XIII. The result indicates that CJADE-M is significantly better than CGSA-P. A parallel strategy is similar to a greedy algorithm which needs much computational time, while the memory-based strategy has an adaptive mechanism to help the algorithm choose a proper optimization method. Each strategy has its own advantage and its performance may depend on the underlying optimization algorithm. The relation between a search strategy and optimization algorithm is one of our researches in the future.

div.head: E. Dimension Size Analysis
div.p: The search ability of optimization algorithms decreases as the problem dimension grows. We investigate the performance of CJADE-M and JADE on the functions with different dimensions. Four dimensions are set to be 2, 10, 30, and 50. The

div.head: F. Population Size Analysis
div.p: F (mutation factor), CR (crossover probability), and N (population size) are three main parameters that influence the performance of DE [2]. Although JADE uses an adaptive method to automatically update parameters F and CR, the population size needs to be further discussed. To analyze the influence of N on CJADE-M and JADE, we test two kinds of population sizes, i.e., 30 and 50. In the supplementary material shows their experimental results. The corresponding Wilcoxon signed-rank test results are listed in Table XV. From it, we conclude that the R + value at N = 30 is greater than it at N = 50, signifying that a smaller population size can benefit CLS. Both p-values are smaller than 0.05, verifying that CJADE-M outperforms JADE at different population sizes.

div.head: G. Performance on CEC2018 Benchmark Functions
div.p: CJADE-M has shown superior results on CEC2005 and CEC2013 benchmark functions. In order to further evaluate its performance, recent 29 CEC2018 benchmark functions [70] are adopted. Five state-of-the-art DEs, i.e., SaDE, SHADE, JADE, jDE, and EPSDE, and three other optimization algorithms, including TLBO [11], fireworks algorithm (FWA) [71], and ABC algorithm [72], [73] are used to compare with CJADE-M. The experimental results are given in the supplementary material. Statistical results are listed in Table XVI. From it, we conclude that CJADE-M significantly outperforms five DEs and three other algorithms according to p-value. The comparison indicates that CJADE-M is still the best on recent CEC2018 benchmark functions, further demonstrating its remarkable performance versus some state-of-the-art DEs and other optimization algorithms. We also conclude that CJADE-M uses an effective search mechanism independent of functions and is suitable for diverse functions.

div.head: H. Parameter Sensitivity Analysis of CJADE-M
div.p: CJADE-M has two important parameter ρ and L that influence search radius and information memories. To guarantee the optimal performance of CJADE-M, parameters ρ and L are analyzed on 29 CEC2018 benchmark functions. Four values are used for each parameter, i.e., ρ ∈ {0.999, 0.988, 0.98, 0.9} and L ∈ {25, 50, 75, 100}. Sixteen parametric combinations are conducted to optimize each function. The experimental results are shown in the supplementary material and statistical results are exhibited in Table XVII. From it, we find that CJADE-M with ρ = 0.988 and L = 50 significantly outperforms it with other values except for ρ = 0.9 and L = 50 and ρ = 0.988 and L = 25 according to p Bonf [74]. But under a significant level of α = 0.1, we can conclude that ρ = 0.988 and L = 50 are the best parameter setting for CJADE-M.

div.head: I. Meta-Lamarckian Learning Method
div.p: CJADE-M uses an effective memory and selection mechanism to invoke chaotic maps. To compare its performance, we add the Meta-Lamarckian learning method [75] into CJADE to form a new variant CJADE-MLL. A Meta-Lamarckian learning method is to adaptively select suitable one from multiple local search strategies to improve algorithm performance. It gives a greater selection chance to a local search strategy with higher fitness improvement. In this method, a reward η is calculated as
div.formula: η = β p f -c f μ (18
S k,j = β f X g (k) -f X j g (k) μ . (19
div.p: Then, the chosen probability of each chaotic map is calculated via (16). CJADE-M and CJADE-MLL are measured on 29 CEC2018 benchmark functions. The experimental results are given in the supplementary material and statistical results are listed in Table XVIII. From it, CJADE-M significantly outperforms CJADE-MLL, implying that its memory mechanism is superior to the Meta-Lamarckian learning method for recording chaotic maps.

div.head: J. Computational Complexity
div.p: CJADE-M has shown the superior property for various functions and problems. Next, we primarily show its computational time complexity together with JADE's.

In JADE, the time complexity for initializing the population is O(N) where N is the population size. Calculating the fitness needs O(N). In addition, the generation of a mutation vector holds the computational complexity of O(N 2 ) in the worst case. The crossover operation and the fitness calculation of offspring need O(3N) and O(N), respectively. Therefore, an overall time complexity of JADE within one generation in the worst case is O(N 2 ).

CJADE-M is improved on the basis of JADE. It needs O(12N) in generating chaotic sequences. The CLS costs O(N) in each generation. Therefore, an overall time complexity of CJADE-M in the worst case is O(N 2 ) which is the same as JADE. Additionally, the CPU running time needed by CJADE-M is about 1.25 times as much as that costed by JADE averagely for all tested problems. The redundant time is caused mainly by the success and failure memories whereas they have time complexity O(1). In conclusion, both of JADE and CJADE-M are computationally efficient.
Besides, the computational time complexity of SaDE, SHADE, jDE, and EPSDE is also calculated. They all have O(N 2 ) in the worst case. Thus, CJADE-M is also as computationally efficient as them.

div.head: VIII. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this article, we combine chaos with a conventional meta-heuristic algorithm JADE to yield a new improved version called CJADE, and creatively propose four variants, i.e., CJADE-S, CJADE-R, CJADE-P, and CJADE-M. Different from the conventional chaotic search just using a single chaotic multiple chaos embedded CJADEs utilize distinctive properties from different chaotic maps to effectively enhance the performance of CLS. The experiments are carried out on 53 benchmark functions and four real-world engineering problems. The main conclusions drawn from the experiments are listed as follows.

1) Most single chaos embedded CJADEs perform better than conventional JADE, indicating that CLS can be used to improve the performance of JADE. 2) CJADE-M performs the best among JADE, CJADEs, some state-of-the-art DEs, and other optimization algorithms, demonstrating that the memory-based selection of multiple chaos in CLS can achieve the best result.

3) The performance of CJADE-M on four real-world engineering problems suggests that it is a promising and effective method for solving various engineering optimization problems. 4) The further discussions regarding details of CJADE-M highlight its superiority and efficiency. Throughout our experiments, we find that adjusting the search radius can affect the results of specific functions. In this article, we use a common shrinking search radius for CJADEs. However, given different characteristics of specific problems, an adaptive search radius selection method should be considered in future work. In addition, the memory-based CLS may also be applied to other optimization algorithms to further enhance the latter's search performances.

div.p: This work was supported in part by the National Natural Science Foundation of China under Grant 61673403 and Grant 61872271, and in part by Japan Society for the Promotion of Science KAKENHI under Grant JP17K12751. This article was recommended by Associate Editor L. Wang.
Shangce Gao (M'11-SM'16) received the Ph.D. degree in innovative life science from the University of Toyama, Toyama, Japan, in 2011.

He is currently an Associate Professor with the Faculty of Engineering, University of Toyama. His current research interests include nature-inspired technologies, mobile computing, machine learning, and neural networks for real-world applications.

Yang Yu received the B.E. degree in civil engineering from the Yancheng Institute of Technology, Yancheng, China, in 2014, and the M.S. degree in artificial intelligence from the University of Toyama, Toyama, Japan, in 2017, where he is currently pursuing the Ph.D. degree in artificial intelligence.
His main research interests are data mining, optimization problems, and nature-inspired algorithms.

Yirui Wang received the B.S. and M.S. degrees in artificial intelligence from the College of Information Sciences and Technology, Donghua University, Shanghai, China, in 2014 and 2017, respectively. He is currently pursuing the Ph.D. degree in artificial intelligence with the University of Toyama, Toyama, Japan.
His research interests are computational intelligence, swarm intelligent algorithms, and combinatorial optimizations.
Jiahai Wang (M'07-SM'19) received the Ph.D. degree in artificial intelligence from the University of Toyama, Toyama, Japan, in 2005.
In 2005, he joined Sun Yat-sen University, Guangzhou, China, where he is currently a Professor. His main research interest includes computational intelligence and its applications.
